tit.cmt: 侍従の説明を追加しました。

sen.j: 侍従（じじゅう）とは、広義では（しばしば高貴な立場の）ある人物に付き従い、身の回りの世話などをする行為、または従う者そのものを指す。
sen.e: The term "chamberlain" refers to a person who serves another person (generally a noble person) to take care of his or her personal affairs, and its Japanese equivalent term "jiju" also represents a chamberlain's service itself in a broad sense.

The term "chamberlain" refers to a person who serves another person (generally a noble person) to take care of his or her personal affairs, and its Japanese equivalent term "jiju" also represents a chamberlain's service itself in a broad sense.

The term "chamberlain" refers to a person who serves another person (generally a noble person) to take care of his or her personal affairs, and its Japanese equivalent term "jiju" also represents a chamberlain's service itself in a broad sense.

sen.j: 日本においては、特に天皇に側近奉仕する文官や位を意味するため、この項目ではこれについて解説する。
sen.e: In Japan, this term specially refers to a civil officer who serves an emperor or the rank of that person, and this section describes these.
In Japan, this term specially refers to a civil officer who serves an emperor or the rank of that person, and this section describes these.
In Japan, this term specially refers to a civil officer who serves an emperor or the rank of that person, and this section describes these.

sen.j: なお、武官による侍従武官や皇太子に付される東宮侍従については、それぞれ項目を参照のこと。
sen.e: For details about aides-de-camp to His Majesty and details about chamberlains to the Crown Prince, refer to each section.
For details about aides-de-camp to the Emperor and details about chamberlains to the Crown Prince, refer to each section.
sen.cmt: His Majestyだと国王陛下のニュアンスなので、天皇としました。
sen.e: For details about aides-de-camp to the Emperor and details about chamberlains to the Crown Prince, refer to each section.

tit.e: Chamberlains under a System of Centralized Government Based on the Ritsuryo Codes
Chamberlains under a System of Centralized Government Based on the Ritsuryo Codes
Chamberlains under a System of Centralized Government Based on the Ritsuryo Codes

sen.j: 日本の官制の侍従は、和名を「まへつきみ（まえつきみ）・おもとびと・おもとびとまちぎみ」、唐名は拾遺などという。
sen.e: Chamberlains were called 'maetsukimi,' 'omotobito,' or 'omotobitomachigi' under a system of government based on the ritsuryo codes, and the tomyo (Tang name) of this position was shui.
sen.cmt: 原文に「日本の官制」とありますが、リンク先の用語と混ざっているようです。原文を確認し、「律令官制」として訳出いたしました。
sen.e: Chamberlains were called 'maetsukimi,' 'omotobito,' or 'omotobitomachigi' in Japanese under a system of government based on the ritsuryo codes, and the tomyo (Tang name) of this position was shui.
sen.cmt: in Japaneseを加え、「和名を」の訳として追加しました。
sen.e: Chamberlains were called 'maetsukimi,' 'omotobito,' or 'omotobitomachigi' in Japanese under a system of government based on the ritsuryo codes, and the tomyo (Tang name) of this position was shui.

sen.j: 大宝律令によると、従五位下相当官で、中務省に属するとされた。
sen.e: According to the Taiho Code, chamberlains were equivalent to Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade), and they belonged to the Ministry of Central Affairs.
According to the Taiho Code, chamberlains were equivalent to Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade), and they belonged to the Ministry of Central Affairs.
According to the Taiho Code, chamberlains were equivalent to Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade), and they belonged to the Ministry of Central Affairs.

sen.j: 定員8名であったが、時代と共に増員され、最大20名程まで増員された。
sen.e: Although the prescribed number of chamberlains was initially eight, it was changed as time went by, and eventually it was increased to a maximum number of 20.
Although the prescribed number of chamberlains was initially eight, it was changed as time went by, and eventually it was increased to a maximum number of 20.
Although the prescribed number of chamberlains was initially eight, it was changed as time went by, and eventually it was increased to a maximum number of 20.

sen.j: うち3名は少納言を兼任した。
sen.e: Three of them were also appointed Shonagon (lesser councilor of state).
Three of them were also appointed as Shonagon (lesser councilor of state).
Three of them were also appointed as Shonagon (lesser councilor of state).

sen.j: 侍衛官であるため帯剣した。
sen.e: A chamberlain always had a sword because his position was also regarded as an Imperial escort.
A chamberlain always had a sword because his position was also regarded as an Imperial escort.
A chamberlain always had a sword because his position was also regarded as an Imperial escort.

sen.j: 平安時代に蔵人所が設置されてその役割が急速に縮小され、多くは大納言、中納言、参議が兼任するようになる。
sen.e: Once the Kurodo-dokoro (Board of Archivists) was established in the Heian period, the role of chamberlains rapidly became less important, and eventually, most chamberlains had another function such as Dainagon (chief councilor of state), Chunagon (vice-councilor of state) or Sangi (councillor).

Once the Kurodo-dokoro (Board of Archivists) was established in the Heian period, the role of chamberlains rapidly became less important, and eventually, Dainagon (chief councilor of state), Chunagon (vice-councilor of state) or Sangi (councillor) also served as chamberlain.
sen.cmt: 兼任するのは大納言等と解釈し、書き換えました。
sen.e: Once the Kurodo-dokoro (Board of Archivists) was established in the Heian period, the role of chamberlains rapidly became less important, and eventually, Dainagon (chief councilor of state), Chunagon (vice-councilor of state) or Sangi (councillor) also served as chamberlain.

sen.j: 中世においては、侍従は専ら儀礼を担当することなり、天皇に側近奉仕する官としての色合いが薄れた。
sen.e: Chamberlains spent all their working time in preparing for ceremonies in the medieval period, and their original characteristics as an emperor's close staff were gradually lost.
Chamberlains were primarily in charge of preparation for ceremonies in the medieval period, and their original characteristics as an emperor's close staff were gradually lost.
sen.cmt: 「もっぱら～担当する」の部分を書き換えました。
sen.e: Chamberlains were primarily in charge of preparation for ceremonies in the medieval period, and their original characteristics as an emperor's close staff were gradually lost.

sen.j: 定員が8名の頃、92名の次侍従が置かれ、侍従と併せて100名の定員とした。
sen.e: In the period that eight chamberlains served at the Imperial Court, they also had 92 associate chamberlains, so there were 100 chamberlains in total.
In the period that eight chamberlains served at the Imperial Court, they also had 92 associate chamberlains, so there were 100 chamberlains in total.
In the period that eight chamberlains served at the Imperial Court, they also had 92 associate chamberlains, so there were 100 chamberlains in total.

sen.j: 次侍従は四、五位で長年の勤務実績がある者が、八省、その他の役所から選抜され任命された。
sen.e: Officers who were at the Fourth or the Fifth Rank and had many years of career were selected from the hassho (literally, "eight ministries," which is a general term for Ministry of Central Affairs, Ministry of Ceremonial, Ministry of Civil Administration, Ministry of Popular Affairs, Ministry of Military, Ministry of Justice, Ministry of the Treasury, and Ministry of Imperial Household) and other agencies and appointed as an associate chamberlain.

Officers who were at the Fourth or the Fifth Rank and had many years of career were selected from the hassho (literally, "eight ministries," which is a general term for Ministry of Central Affairs, Ministry of Ceremonial, Ministry of Civil Administration, Ministry of Popular Affairs, Ministry of Military, Ministry of Justice, Ministry of the Treasury, and Ministry of Imperial Household) and other agencies and appointed as associate chamberlains.
sen.cmt: 数の一致をさせました。
sen.e: Officers who were at the Fourth or the Fifth Rank and had many years of career were selected from the hassho (literally, "eight ministries," which is a general term for Ministry of Central Affairs, Ministry of Ceremonial, Ministry of Civil Administration, Ministry of Popular Affairs, Ministry of Military, Ministry of Justice, Ministry of the Treasury, and Ministry of Imperial Household) and other agencies and appointed as associate chamberlains.

sen.j: 職掌は天皇の側で雑務を担当した。
sen.e: Their function was to stay with the emperor and address miscellaneous business.
Their function was to stay with the emperor and to address miscellaneous business.
Their function was to stay with the emperor and to address miscellaneous business.

sen.j: 1869年 （明治2年）、宮内省に属することとなった。
sen.e: In 1869, it was decided that chamberlains should belong to the Ministry of Imperial Household.
In 1869, it was decided that chamberlains should belong to the Ministry of Imperial Household.
In 1869, it was decided that chamberlains should belong to the Ministry of Imperial Household.

sen.j: 1871年にはその長として侍従長が置かれ、徳大寺実則・河瀬真孝・東久世通禧の3人が任命された。
sen.e: A position called the Grand Chamberlain was established as leading chamberlains in 1871, and Sanetsune TOKUDAIJI, Masataka KAWASE, and Michitomi HIGASHIKUZE assumed this position.
A position called the Grand Chamberlain was established as a head of chamberlains in 1871, and Sanetsune TOKUDAIJI, Masataka KAWASE, and Michitomi HIGASHIKUZE assumed this position.
A position called the Grand Chamberlain was established as a head of chamberlains in 1871, and Sanetsune TOKUDAIJI, Masataka KAWASE, and Michitomi HIGASHIKUZE assumed this position.

sen.j: 宮内省官制（明治40年皇室令第3号）によると下記のようにされていた。
sen.e: The Regulations of the Ministry of Imperial Household (Imperial Household Order No. 3 of 1907) said as follows.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Regulations of the Ministry of Imperial Household (Imperial Household Order No. 3 of 1907) said as follows.
The Regulations of the Ministry of Imperial Household (Imperial Household Order No. 3 of 1907) said as follows.

sen.j: 「侍従長ハ親任又ハ勅任トス常侍奉仕シ侍従職ヲ統轄シ便宜事ヲ奏シ旨ヲ宣ス」
sen.e: "The Grand Chamberlain should be appointed personally or officially by the Emperor, and he should serve the Emperor all the time; additionally, he also has to take care of other chamberlains and report to the Emperor."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: "The Grand Chamberlain should be appointed personally or officially by the Emperor, and he should serve the Emperor all the time; additionally, he also has to take care of other chamberlains and report to the Emperor."

"The Grand Chamberlain should be appointed personally or officially by the Emperor, and he should serve the Emperor all the time; additionally, he also has to take care of other chamberlains and report to the Emperor."

sen.j: 「侍従ハ……奏任トス側近ノ事ヲ分掌ス」
sen.e: "Chamberlains should be appointed with the Emperor's approval, and they should work together to address the Emperor's personal or private affairs."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: "Chamberlains should be appointed with the Emperor's approval, and they should work together to address the Emperor's personal or private affairs."
"Chamberlains should be appointed with the Emperor's approval, and they should work together to address the Emperor's personal or private affairs."

sen.j: 第二次世界大戦後は、一時期の宮内府時代を経て宮内庁侍従職に属する。
sen.e: After World War II, chamberlains temporarily belonged to the Imperial Household Office before they were attached to the Board of Chamberlains, the Imperial Household Agency.
After World War II, chamberlains temporarily belonged to the Imperial Household Office before they belonged to the Board of Chamberlains, the Imperial Household Agency.
After World War II, chamberlains temporarily belonged to the Imperial Household Office before they belonged to the Board of Chamberlains, the Imperial Household Agency.

sen.j: 国家公務員法（昭和22年法律第120号）施行以降も、侍従は同法の適用を受けない特別職とされ、一級官・二級官などの区別が存続していた（官記に「二級に叙する」などと記載）。
sen.e: After the National Public Service Law (Act No. 120 of 1947) was put in force, the position of chamberlains was still a special position in government service exempted from the application of this law, and their classification such as the first grade officer and the second grade officer still existed (some descriptions such as "he was granted the second grade" were seen in official reports).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After the National Public Service Law (Act No. 120 of 1947) was put in force, the position of chamberlains was still a special position in government service exempted from the application of this law, and their classification such as the first grade officer and the second grade officer still existed (some descriptions such as "he was granted the second grade" were seen in official reports).

After the National Public Service Law (Act No. 120 of 1947) was put in force, the position of chamberlains was still a special position in government service exempted from the application of this law, and their classification such as the first grade officer and the second grade officer still existed (some descriptions such as "he was granted the second grade" were seen in official reports).

sen.j: が、中央省庁再編後は官記への級別記載はされなくなった。
sen.e: However, their grades were not mentioned in any official reports any more after the reorganization of central government ministries and agencies.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, their grades were no longer mentioned in any official reports after the reorganization of the central government ministries and agencies.
sen.cmt: any more をno longer としました。
sen.e: However, their grades were no longer mentioned in any official reports after the reorganization of the central government ministries and agencies.

sen.j: 侍従長の職は認証官であり、その任免は天皇により認証される。
sen.e: As the position of the Grand Chamberlain is an attestation official, this position is appointed and dismissed by the Emperor.
As the position of the Grand Chamberlain is an attestation official, this position is appointed and dismissed by the Emperor.
As the position of the Grand Chamberlain is an attestation official, this position is appointed and dismissed by the Emperor.
